Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Short-and Long-term Sediment Dynamics Following Wildfire in Chaparral Environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID project focuses on production and delivery of dry ravel, a characteristic and immediate post-fire response on steep slopes in the western USA. Dry ravel arises from a dry-season transport process whereby gravel sediment moving down hillslopes by gravity becomes trapped by vegetation. This material provides a significant sediment source into river channels after wildfire in chaparral environments. The investigators will quantify the volume of dry ravel sediment deposited along channel margins as a result of the Springs Fire that burned Big Sycamore Canyon in southern California during May 2013. Terrestrial laser scanning before and after the rainy season (which typically begins around October 1) will capture initial changes in landscape topography. These data will be augmented by field surveys. Data collected during the first post-fire year are important for developing models of the dynamics of dry ravel. The investigators have geomorphic data spanning over 25 years for Big Sycamore Canyon and two comparable basins nearby with different fire histories--a tributary to north fork Matilija Creek that burned completely during the July 1985 Wheeler Fire-- and a tributary to Malibu Creek that has remained unburned. Comparing dry ravel processes at these three sites will enable a direct comparison of both short- and long-term sediment dynamics following wildfire in chaparral environments.

Developing a predictive understanding of both short- and long-term effects of wildfire is critical, especially in an era of changing climate that has increased frequencies and magnitudes of wildfires. Yet, accurately predicting post-fire effects remains elusive, and physically-based models of post-fire runoff and erosion are still being developed. The proposed project will integrate research and education by involving undergraduate students from California State University, Channel Islands (CSUCI). These students will pursue their capstone undergraduate coursework while assisting the PIs with field data collection and analysis. Two of these students are participants of the Hispanic-Serving Institutes ACCESO (Achieving a Cooperative College Education Through STEM Opportunities) Research Assistant Program on the CSUCI campus. These students will receive valuable research experiences including training in use of cutting-edge technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mountains of the western United States are increasingly susceptible to wildfire as a result of warming climates. Wildfires have significant indirect effects on hydrologic and geomorphologic processes that ultimately impacts human society.  In the Mediterranean chaparral environment of southern California, wildfire increases sediment transport on hillslopes by releasing dry ravel after fire. Dry ravel is a dry-season erosion process whereby gravel-sized sediment moving down hillslopes by gravity becomes temporarily trapped by vegetation. Removal of vegetation by burning releases this sediment and enables its accumulation at the base of hillslopes along channel margins. Once rainfall occurs and generates runoff, these materials are quickly mobilized, contributing a significant source of sediment into river channels. This RAPID (rapid-response) project documented short- and long-term sediment dynamics in chaparral fluvial systems in southern California following the May 2013 Springs Fire. In Big Sycamore Canyon, burned by the Springs Fire, field surveys of longitudinal profiles, cross sections, and grain size distributions together with Terrestrial LiDAR Scanning documented dry ravel deposits and channel morphology in September 2013, before rainfall occurred. Repeated measurements conducted during March/April 2014 quantified changes in channels and hillslopes in response to a storm that occurred on 28 Feb – 2 Mar 2014. Concurrently, field data collected in nearby Cold Creek and Matilija Creek, burned 20-30 years ago, enabled comparison of long-term channel responses to wildfire. Results showed extensive transformation of channel morphology in Big Sycamore Canyon in response to the small storm of 2014. Yet, no significant changes were observed in Cold Creek and Matilija Creek. These results indicate the magnitude of the short-term channel responses induced by fire. They also suggest that 20-30 years is sufficient time for geomorphic recovery after fire in the chaparral environment.  The data and findings from this project assist with planning and mitigation efforts to reduce hazards from future wildfires, which are inevitably increasing. The study also strengthened collaboration among academic institutions and government and non-government agencies. The project additionally enabled training of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in field and laboratory methods.
